content.statement: aortemerg-001-contained-rupture is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Aortic-Dissection Diagnosis that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding aortemerg-001-contained-rupture helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of aortemerg-001-contained-rupture include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of aortemerg-001-contained-rupture.

definitions_glossary.concept: A fundamental idea or notion in the domain
definitions_glossary.property: A characteristic or attribute of an entity
definitions_glossary.relationship: A connection or association between concepts

typical: Severe abdominal, back, or flank pain (often present for hours to days)
Pain may be positional or worsened by movement
History of known AAA in many cases
atypical_concerning: Syncope with recovery (suggests transient hypotension from initial rupture)
Groin or testicular pain from tracking hematoma
Leg weakness from retroperitoneal mass effect on lumbar plexus
Flank ecchymosis (Grey Turner sign) - late finding
dangerous_misconceptions: Stable vitals = time for extensive workup
Patient can tolerate transport to distant facility

pathophysiology.mechanism: Aneurysm wall ruptures, blood extravasates into retroperitoneum
pathophysiology.tamponade: Posterior pararenal fascia and surrounding tissues contain hemorrhage
pathophysiology.hematoma_formation: Clot forms in retroperitoneal space, providing additional tamponade
pathophysiology.progression_risk: Hypertension, Valsalva, straining, or spontaneous clot failure → free rupture

CT_angiography.periaortic_hematoma: Blood surrounding the aneurysm, tracking into retroperitoneum
CT_angiography.draped_aorta_sign: Posterior aortic wall conforming to vertebral body contour (loss of retroperitoneal fat plane)
CT_angiography.crescent_sign: Crescentic high-attenuation within thrombus (acute intramural blood)
CT_angiography.irregular_contour: Focal outward bulge or loss of smooth aneurysm outline
CT_angiography.contrast_extravasation: Active bleeding within contained space (ominous sign)

imaging_findings.ultrasound: Can identify AAA and free fluid but limited for rupture characterization
imaging_findings.plain_film: Loss of psoas margin, soft tissue mass (low sensitivity)

diagnosis: High clinical suspicion in known AAA with new pain
CT angiography is the gold standard for diagnosis and surgical planning
Do NOT delay imaging if patient stable enough - guides repair approach
Clinical diagnosis alone sufficient if classic triad and unstable

immediate_principles: Minimal crystalloid - use blood products if needed
Expedited repair - time is critical even in 'stable' patient

EVAR_first.requirements: Adequate landing zones, available expertise and inventory

open_repair.indication: Unsuitable anatomy, hemodynamic collapse, EVAR unavailable
open_repair.approach: Midline laparotomy, suprarenal or infrarenal clamp
open_repair.warning: Loss of retroperitoneal tamponade at laparotomy may cause precipitous decompensation

pitfalls: Aggressive resuscitation disrupts clot and converts contained to free rupture
Transport to distant center risks decompensation en route
Opening abdomen before aortic control equipment ready can be fatal

definition.@value: Aortic rupture in which hemorrhage is tamponaded by retroperitoneal tissues, providing temporary hemodynamic stability but requiring emergent repair before conversion to free rupture

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Define contained rupture and explain its pathophysiology
Recognize clinical presentations of contained rupture
Identify CT imaging findings diagnostic of contained rupture
Apply permissive hypotension principles to prevent clot disruption
Understand why EVAR may be preferred (preserves retroperitoneal tamponade)
Recognize the dangers of aggressive resuscitation in contained rupture
clinical_pearls: A patient with contained rupture may walk into the ED - don't be fooled by stability
The 'draped aorta' sign indicates loss of normal retroperitoneal tissue plane
Contained rupture is 'one cough away' from exsanguination
EVAR preserves retroperitoneal tamponade - no laparotomy-induced decompensation
Opening the abdomen without aortic control can cause immediate hemodynamic collapse
Grey Turner sign (flank ecchymosis) is a late finding - do not wait for it
